patternTriggers: When you need to find pairs that sum to a target, two pointers work perfectly on sorted arrays.

approaches.name: Brute Force
approaches.intuition: Check every possible pair to see if they sum to target.
approaches.approach: Use nested loops to examine all combinations.
steps: Loop through each element with index i
For each i, loop through remaining elements with index j
Check if nums[i] + nums[j] equals target
Return [i, j] when match is found

complexity.timeExplanation: Two nested loops iterate through all pairs
complexity.spaceExplanation: Only using constant space for variables

approaches.name: Hash Map (Optimal)
approaches.intuition: Instead of checking all pairs, use a hash map to store seen numbers and check if complement exists.
approaches.approach: As we iterate, check if (target - current number) exists in our map.
steps: If complement exists in map, return [map[complement], i]
Store nums[i] with index i in map

complexity.timeExplanation: Single pass with O(1) hash lookups
complexity.spaceExplanation: Hash map stores up to n elements

commonMistakes: Using the same element twice (returning [i, i])
Not checking if complement exists before adding to map
Assuming array is sorted when it's not
hints: What do you need to find for each number?
Can you store previously seen numbers?
Which data structure provides O(1) lookup?
followUp: What if the array is sorted? Can you optimize space?
